bestBHT.bht: An uncircumcised man who fully lives up to the moral requirements of the law is just as justified as someone who is within the covenant of circumcision. The act of fulfilling the law is what truly matters, not the outward sign of circumcision. Therefore, if someone who is circumcised does not keep the law, they are no better than an uncircumcised heathen. In the end, even those who are naturally uncircumcised will condemn those who transgress the law.

Henry Alford: I prefer to regard this verse not as a continuation of the question, but as a separate emphatic assertion."
...an uncircumcised man could fully act up to the (moral) requirements of the law."
Through is here used of the state in which the man is when he does the act, regarded as the medium through which the act is done.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For circumcision—that is, One's being within the covenant of which circumcision was the outward sign and seal.
Verily profiteth, if thou keep the law—if the inward reality correspond to the outward sign.
Otherwise, thou art no better than the uncircumcised heathen.
Albert Barnes: Which is the natural state of man; his condition before he is admitted to any of the unique rites of the Jewish religion.
Shall not a pagan man who has none of your external privileges, if he keeps the law, condemn you who are Jews?
For a similar mode of expression, see Matthew 12:41-42.
John Calvin: They continued, though they had the outward rite, to neglect the spiritual worship of God, even piety, justice, judgment, and truth, which are the chief matters of the law.
The outward performance of the law, it being written, as opposed to what is spiritual or inward.
Philip Schaff: Shall judge. This verb stands in emphatic position. The reference is not to the direct, but to the indirect, judgment of the last day, when the conduct of the Gentile will, by comparison, show the true moral attitude of the sinning Jew.
Hence the aggravated guilt of one who in such circumstances is a transgressor of this law.
The absence of the article here (in the original) ought to be conclusive against the notion that Paul omits the article only when he means 'law' in general.
Archibald T. Robertson: If it fulfill the law... to finish, continually fulfilling to the end (as would be necessary).
Judge thee...unusual position of thee so far from the verb judge.
With the letter and circumcision... with the advantage of.
John Gill: And shall not uncircumcision which is by nature... fulfil the law in Christ, they will judge thee, the circumcision..."
The men of Nineveh and the queen of the south will condemn the men of that generation, in which Christ lived...
Who by the letter and circumcision transgress the law...
John Wesley: Yea, the uncircumcision that is by nature...fulfilling the law."
Who by the letter and circumcision...transgressest the law.

bhtAttempts.bht: An uncircumcised man who fully lives up to the moral requirements of the law is just as justified as someone who is within the covenant of circumcision. The act of fulfilling the law is what truly matters, not the outward sign of circumcision. Therefore, if someone who is circumcised does not keep the law, they are no better than an uncircumcised heathen. It is through the fulfillment of the law, and not through external privileges, that one will be judged. In the end, even those who are naturally uncircumcised will condemn those who transgress the law, for their actions will reveal their true moral attitude.

An uncircumcised man who fully lives up to the moral requirements of the law is just as justified as someone who is within the covenant of circumcision. The act of fulfilling the law is what truly matters, not the outward sign of circumcision. Therefore, if someone who is circumcised does not keep the law, they are no better than an uncircumcised heathen. In the end, even those who are naturally uncircumcised will condemn those who transgress the law.

If an uncircumcised man could fully act according to the moral requirements of the law, then being within the covenant of circumcision would truly be profitable if one kept the law. However, if one fails to fulfill the law and lives no differently than the uncircumcised, they are no better off than the heathen. The emphasis here is not on judging others, but on recognizing that an uncircumcised pagan who keeps the law may actually condemn those who possess the external privileges of being Jewish. It is in this sense that the men of Nineveh and the queen of the south will condemn the generation of Christ, for they fulfilled the law through their actions while those with the letter and circumcision transgressed it.

If an uncircumcised man could fully act according to the moral requirements of the law, then being within the covenant of circumcision would truly be profitable if one kept the law. However, if one fails to fulfill the law and lives no differently than the uncircumcised, they are no better off than the heathen. The emphasis here is not on judging others, but on recognizing that an uncircumcised pagan who keeps the law may actually condemn those who possess the external privileges of being Jewish.

If an uncircumcised man could fulfill the moral requirements of the law, then being within the covenant of circumcision would truly be profitable if one kept the law. However, if one fails to fulfill the law and lives no differently than the uncircumcised, they are no better than the heathen. It is not about judging others, but about recognizing that an uncircumcised pagan who keeps the law may actually condemn those with external Jewish privileges.
